captions.text:
CHRISTIAN VON KOENIGSEGG:
My name is Christian von
Koenigsegg.

I'm 40 years old and for half
of my life, I've been on the

quest to be a leader in the
hypercar industry utilizing

Swedish design combined with
visionary technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangars of

a former Swedish fighter
jet squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
proudly painted on the back
every Koenigsegg.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

ROBERT SERWANSKI: My name is
Robert Serwanski, and I'm a
test driver of Koenigsegg.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

My job is, basically,
two parts.

I developed the cars and how
they handle performance-wise,

and I also am a part of
the production line.

Production-wise I get an
assembled car, in one piece

you could say, and then
I finalize it.

Finalizing means I do the wheel
alignment, I put in the

brakes, put in the
differential.

I'm with the guys who tune
the engine properly.

Everything is assembled by hand,
so there are, of course,

small differences in every car
and that's why we tune every
car to a specific set up.

And we do a few wheel
alignments, so everything can
settle down.

And once everything works
properly, we all also check
quality of the car, of course.

Every function and every feature
of the car must work.

And so nothing can rattle,
nothing can sound in the car.

Yeah, and we do a lot of driving
and we drive the cars

rather hard, because they
need to work once
they get to the customer.

And a lot of that work is
done on this runway.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

This is a specific car we
did the zero to 300
to zero record in.
I was in 21.19 seconds.
That was a year ago.

It wasn't this cold and
not this windy.

And so, of course, it
was better for the
performance of the car.

And also, right now, in the
videos you saw, we only run on

50% bioethanol, and in the
record videos, we always drive

85%, which is available
at your normal
petrol station in Sweden.

The car was just taken
out on a day.

Christian gave me a call and
said, shall we do test to do
the record?

And we collected some equipment,
got out here, and
just did it, basically.

This was just sort of a stage in
the very fine approaches of
producing the car, really.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

They gave me a call about two
years ago and offered a job.

And I came here, had a few
hours of discussion with

Christian, and we talked about
what the job was about.

And then, obviously, there was
a testing period, where we

went all the job through and
what's supposed to be done,
and how I feel about the car.
And I'm still here.

A day could be everything from
driving for 12 or 16 hours,

and it could be changing an
engine or a gearbox for
development purpose.

So well, there's not one day
that is the other day like,

and that's a good thing
about the job, because
you never get bored.

Well, my tools are, basically,
it's also depending on the
purpose obviously.

Right now, I work a lot
with the gearbox.

We have our own gearbox
management, and for that I

have the engineers, and I have
a computer, and the car.

And also, we need to tune the
gearbox for driving in the

city, or on highway, or doing
zero to 300 to zero.

So if I need to tune the gearbox
for driving into town,
I obviously drive into town.

And that's of course doing
50k and not 200.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

So everything is through one
cable through OBD, is simply
accessible through one program,
one cable, one interface.

So everything, I choose what I
would like to see, and what I
would like to adjust.

If I would like to go to a
certain gear, for instance, I

have the behavior of a gear,
the clutch, the shift time,

the torque out, everything
we control.

And everything can be logged
while we do it.

It's also the same thing here,
even though we have thousands

of parameters, there's no
purpose of really seeing it

all at once, because it would
look something like this, and
it just looks messy.

I can connect that, what I see
in the log, to what I sense.

And I can see that, for
instance, OK, this clutch

closes a little bit too fast
or we don't cut the torque

fast enough, or whatever
I see or sense.
And then I change it.

And then I drive
it again, try.

So it takes a really long time
to adjust, because you have a
range of 1,000 to 7,000 revs.
You have seven gears.

So it's quite many cases to
solve and get really good.

It's a combination between
man and machine, really.

I think that we hope to do,
well, we want to do the best
car in the world, basically.

And I think we're on a
good way to do it.

It's a very extreme car in all
ends, but you can really put

your grandma in it and just
explain the pedal function, if

she doesn't have a pedal car
already, and let her drive.

Because it is, really,
that easy to drive.

Of course, it's wide and it's
low, and all those parts, but
it's really easy to drive.

And of course, when you
start pushing it, I
think you need to be--

it will not kill you, but you
need to know what you're doing

to really be able to enjoy
the car fully out.

Because that is when it really
comes to its soul, or whatever
you like to call it.
It come alive, correct.

You can still have plenty of
fun just driving along with

hitting full throttle and full
break and turning, but it's a
really refined tool.

A lot of engineers, prior to my
time, and during my time,

and also, what I have done with
the car and all the other

people, there's a lot of effort
put into it, that it

should be very perfect
in its behavior.

So we actually enjoy it when
people use their cars, because

that's what they are meant
to do, to use them.

Yeah we don't usually do
drifting or sliding for the

purpose of sliding, but that
could be a byproduct of

testing something
else, of course.

And when we do a lot of testing
on the limit for the

car to, for instance, prevent a
behavior of the car breaking
out or spinning away too easy.

And then we need to go past that
point to really tell what

would happen and how
the car behaves.

So we do all the adjusting
and behavior.

And how we would like
the car to feel is
done without anything.

And then we put ABS on, we put
double train differential on,

we put the stability
control on.

So we only have those as you
know as your safety line,

whatever you'd like to call it,
to prevent nasty things
from happening.

But if you would take everything
away, we believe

that the car as it is would
be very enjoyable for an
experienced driver.

Now, you can be a good racing
driver and not be a good test

driver, and also the
other way around.

Because the race driver is not
always about feeling the car

100% or putting very
good lap times.

A race driver can be at the top,
because he knows how to

fight his way through the field
and he has a fast, a

good pace enough to keep
that first place.

But that doesn't actually mean
that he needs to be the

fastest if he would go
to a time attack.

So that's also the difference,
that you must want to learn
what is happening.

And, of course, an input that
something is understeer or

oversteer might be good enough
for an engineer.

But if you can tell the engineer
it understeers, but

at the same time, it's too soft,
maybe we should check

the springs or the
anti-roll bar.

So that's just understeer,
because understeer could be,
well, a lot of things.

So I think, well, it's always
about the good compromise,
really, that you need to have.
-And having fun.

ROBERT SERWANSKI:
And having fun.
That's important.

You can never forget to
have fun, because,
yeah, that's important.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

+ROCKETGUN BOOMBS
Nope. Wolfgang Dürheimer trashed Keonigsegg in the press, and challenged 
them. Then Keonigsegg asked to use the track, as there are no other place 
to do it. Then Dürheimer told Koenigsegg "No". Then Koenigsegg released a 
statement and information confirming the matter, which of course was 
emberrassing to VW and Dürheimer. In turn fat fuck Dürheimer now acting 
like a spoiled little upset brat, banned Christian and his brand from the 
site.
